docs.lead_paragraph: Ordering the wrong test, missing results and forgetting to notify patients are among the many testing mistakes that occur routinely at the offices of family doctors, a new study shows.

headline.main: Testing Mistakes at the Family Doctor

docs.abstract: A series of mistakes involving medical testing may prevent patients from getting the right test or ever learning the real result.
docs.snippet: A series of mistakes involving medical testing may prevent patients from getting the right test or ever learning the real result.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bill Gwatney, the chairman of the Arkansas Democratic Party, was shot in his office in Little Rock and died later, police officials said.

byline.contributor: Robbie Brown contributed reporting from Atlanta, and John M. Hubbell from Little Rock, Ark.
byline.original: By SHAILA DEWAN and STEVE BARNES

docs.lead_paragraph: The turning point in Tim Kaine's campaign for Virginia governor in 2005 was an advertisement by his opponent featuring a father whose son had been murdered by a man Mr. Kaine represented on death row. ''Tim Kaine says that Adolf Hitler doesn't qualify for the death penalty,'' said the outraged father. ''The people of Virginia are entitled to know just what Tim Kaine is and what he stands for.''

headline.main: Charismatic Governor Rises to the Short List

docs.abstract: Article in series The Prospects; Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama's campaign is eying Virginia Gov Tim Kaine as potential running mate; Kaine made his mark in 2005 gubernatorial campaign as man of faith who could talk about religion without making it seem like prop, and as candidate capable of winning in Republican state; civil rights lawyer is inspiring speaker who eludes ideological labels; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: (Correction appended) From Louise Story, a DealBook colleague:

headline.main: Tempers Rise in Analyst's Clash With Florida Bank

docs.abstract: Richard X. Bove, one of the few research analysts to critique banks before the credit bubble popped, has been entangled in a court battle with a regional bank unhappy with his criticisms.
docs.snippet: Richard X. Bove, one of the few research analysts to critique banks before the credit bubble popped, has been entangled in a court battle with a regional bank unhappy with his criticisms.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reining in the runaway freight train otherwise known as the credit default swap market is a rising priority for regulators who oversee banks and insurers. It's a good thing, too, The New York Times' Gretchen Morgenson writes, given the secretive nature of the swaps, the losses they are generating at some companies and the size of the market: $62 trillion in default insurance is outstanding, with a fair value of $2 trillion at the end of 2007.
